Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understandings of Food Insecurity and Urban Space in Kansas City

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores how low-income urban residents experience and respond to food insecurity when organizational efforts that target hunger alleviation are introduced into their neighborhoods. Food insecure populations and economically divested urban spaces are increasingly the focus of municipal government and non-governmental programs, which focus on turning vacant lots into sources of food. But studies indicate that a majority of these programs are not succeeding at including food insecure people of color. This project asks how those served by food justice programs themselves map food access and barriers to food access. How do understandings of those providing and receiving services in food justice programs compare? Food justice initiatives and the creation of urban gardens are often spoken of as strong benefits to urban citizens. But are those the most effective ways to address food insecurity, or do residents express other means of addressing food access and urban vacancy? This data and findings from this project will be disseminated with the aim of contributing to a stronger framework for designing effective policies for more equitable food access in diverse U.S. cities.

This research will be conducted by University of Kentucky doctoral student Chhaya Kolavalli, with direction from Dr. Ann Kingsolver, in Kansas City, Missouri. Kolavalli will conduct extensive participant observation in a fragmented area of the city that officials refer to as a food desert. This section of the city is predominantly occupied by African American residents, and is the site of many food justice programs intended to address food insecurity, making it an ideal site to test the efficacy of these initiatives. Her mixed methods approach will include interviewing, content analysis, interactive social mapping, and focus groups. Interactive social mapping will be used to map and compare food justice activist service providers and service recipients' understandings of food access, race, and urban space. Findings from this research will contribute to understandings of how urban space and hunger are experienced and navigated by low-income minority populations. Results will be shared with Kansas City's municipal government and representatives of non-governmental organizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how low-income minority residents of urban spaces that some would call “food deserts” experience and conceptualize food insecurity and respond to programs training and encouraging them to grow their own food (food justice programs). This research contributes to interdisciplinary scholarship on how those who have been labeled by others as residents of “blighted” urban areas, as part of historically racialized differences in access to resources and political decision-making, speak about their own views of, and actions in, their neighborhoods. The site of this research was in Kansas City, Kansas and Missouri—a metropolitan area with pocketed areas of hypersegregation and food insecurity in which a high number of food justice organizations are currently working to address urban hunger. The methods used in this study of how those both providing and receiving services in urban food justice work included extensive interviewing, participation in neighborhood activities, social mapping, and archival research.

There were several key findings from this research: first, that many urban residents labeled ‘food insecure,’ or as living in ‘food deserts,’ do not find food insecurity or hunger to be their primary concern, even though a majority of the social welfare projects delivered in Kansas City, currently, concern food insecurity. Instead, these urban residents point toward more pressing concerns about affordable, quality rental housing, rising electric and heating bill costs, and unaffordable medical and pharmaceutical bills. Second, this project revealed that a large proportion of Kansas City residents labeled as ‘food insecure’ have family histories of gardening, are aware of how to garden, and may have in fact grown their own food before—but cannot do so on a scale necessary to feed their entire families because of lack of time, physical mobility, and the funds necessary to do so. A third key finding was that many food justice programs in Kansas City tie receipt of food charity or food assistance to participation in nutrition and food safety courses. By participating and observing in these nutrition courses, the researcher found that a majority of class participants were knowledgeable cooks, and were quite aware of how to cook food that fit in well with their poverty-related health conditions—such as diabetes and hypertension. Participation in these mandatory courses to receive food aid was difficult for participants to schedule around their inflexible work schedules, and many voiced feeling demeaned by the program curriculum. Finally, this research corroborated other studies’ findings that increased economic capacity has more of an influence on ‘food insecure’ urban residents’ diets than spatial proximity to fresh produce. In response to farmers markets opening in their ‘food desert’ neighborhoods, many Kansas City residents stated that it would not change where they shop for food—they would still carpool or find transportation to cheaper food outlets, such as chain grocery stores in the suburbs. Many ‘food insecure’ urban residents said they would like to shop at the farmers market, but could not afford to. The findings of this project indicate that the placement of urban farms, community gardens, and farmers markets in ‘food deserts’ is not an effective tactic by itself for addressing urban food insecurity. Such measures would benefit from concurrent cash transfer programs, which would give urban residents the fiscal mobility to take advantage of the increased fruits and produce grown in their neighborhoods.

The research findings are being distributed through academic conference presentations, a doctoral dissertation in anthropology, academic journal articles, community organization meetings in Kansas City, a report to the mayor and city government, and a story on a Kansas City radio station.
